#Data Frames

A **Data Frame** is a list of vectors (columns of data) of equal length.
<br/>
*Example:*

```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}

#Vectors

name <- c("Kenia", "Sabrina", "Kelvin", "Alex")
age <- c("24","24","27","26")
sex <- c("Female","Female","Male","Male")


#Data Frame

dataframe <- data.frame(name, age, sex)
```

<br/>
<br/>

We can use the **print()** command to view the dataframe.

```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE}
print(dataframe)
```

<br/>
<br/>

We can print a **single column**.

```{r, echo=TRUE}

dataframe["name"]
```
We can identify the column by name(above), or index number(below).

```{r, echo=TRUE}

dataframe[1]
```
<br/>
<br/>

We can print a **single row**.

```{r, echo=TRUE}

dataframe[3,]

```
Or **multiple rows**.

```{r, echo=TRUE}

dataframe[1:3,]

#Don't forget the comma!
```
<br/>
<br/>
To **load a dataframe from a file on your computer**

*(You will need the file path for your data file)*
```{r, eval=FALSE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
mydata <- read.csv("filepath")     #Read a .csv file
mydata <- read.delim("filepath")   #Read other table data formats
```


#Filter Data

Load the **dplyr** package.
```{r, eval=FALSE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
install.packages("dplyr")  #Install the package if you haven't before.
library(dplyr) #Load the package
```
```{r, include=FALSE}
library(dplyr)
```


<br/>
<br/>
Load the **starwars** dataframe.
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwarsdata <- starwars

print(starwarsdata)
```
<br/>
<br/>
**Wait**: Before we start filtering, you should understand how the Magrittr package allows us to use pipes to tie together multiple dplyr functions into a single executable command.


Below, we can both define the dataframe, and print the table as we did above with one single script of dplyr commands that are piped together with Magrittr "%>%" piping.
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwarsdata<- starwars%>%   #Step 1: Define the Dataframe
  print()  #Step 2: Print the table

```
<br/>
<br/>
**Filter Columns**  
We will only keep the columns for name, eye color, species, and homeworld.
<br/>
<br/>
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwarsdata%>%
  subset(select=c("name","eye_color","species","homeworld"))

```

<br/>
<br/>
**Notice:** If we call *starwarsdata*, the changes are not retained. We get all of the columns again.
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
print(starwarsdata)
```
<br/>
<br/>
If we want to keep the changes, we need to define a new object. 
*We will define "starwars_subset"*

```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwars_subset<- starwarsdata%>%
  subset(select=c("name","eye_color","species","homeworld"))

print(starwars_subset)

```

<br/>
<br/>
**Filter Rows**
<br/>
<br/>
Let's filter the star wars dataset to show rows representing **Humans Only**.
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwars_subset%>%
  filter(species == "Human")

```

<br/>
<br/>
Let's filter the star wars dataset to show rows representing **Humans with Blue Eyes Only**.
```{r, eval=TRUE, include=TRUE, echo=TRUE}
starwars_subset%>%
  filter(species == "Human" & eye_color== "blue")

```
